comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/mich2009] Obviously this is not the current building housing the National Library. This is the Library in its previous incarnation as the National Parliamentary Library. The National Library split from the Parliamentary Library in 1960 and a new building was built to house it in '68: "The origins of the National Library of Australia go back to the early years after Australian Federation in 1901, when the Commonwealth Parliamentary Library served both Federal Parliament and the nation. In 1927 the Library was moved from Melbourne to Canberra with the relocation of Parliament. An Act of Parliament in 1960 formally separated the National Library from the Parliamentary Library and a new building for the National Library’s growing collections and services was opened on the shores of Lake Burley Griffin, Canberra in August 1968." www.nla.gov.au/history-of-the-library

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/mich2009] This building itself no longer exists. It was knocked down and the Edmund Barton Building designed by Harry Seidler built in its place. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edmund_Barton_Building

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: Yes, typical Seidler, it looks like a car park.
